docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29. -- A dispatch from Colonia, Uruguay, tonight said that a large group of armed civilians had attacked the barracks of the Fourth Artillery Regiment in Montevideo late this afternoon and had been repulsed, but had returned to the...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29. -- A dispatch from Colonia, Uruguay, tonight said that a large group of armed civilians had attacked the barracks of the Fourth Artillery Regiment in Montevideo late this afternoon and had been repulsed, but had returned to the attack and had not been dispersed when the message was sent.
docs.abstract: fighting reaches Montevideo; troops' loyalty doubted

headline.main: FIGHTING REACHES URUGUAY'S CAPITAL; Civilians, Repulsed in Assault on Barracks in Montevideo, Return to the Attack.

docs.snippet: Prices of domestic bonds on the Stock Exchange weakened yesterday, United States Government long-term loans as well as corporation issues. Foreign issues were irregularly higher as the foreign exchanges moved sharply higher against the dollar.
docs.lead_paragraph: Prices of domestic bonds on the Stock Exchange weakened yesterday, United States Government long-term loans as well as corporation issues. Foreign issues were irregularly higher as the foreign exchanges moved sharply higher against the dollar.

headline.main: BONDS TURN DOWN IN ACTIVE TRADING; Federal as Well as Corporate Issues Meet With Selling -- Rails Off Sharply.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30. -- Conflicting reports reaching here regarding battles in various parts of Uruguay today indicate that loyal forces have established contact with revolutionists in three or four places.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30. -- Conflicting reports reaching here regarding battles in various parts of Uruguay today indicate that loyal forces have established contact with revolutionists in three or four places.

headline.main: REBELS IN URUGUAY REPORT VICTORIES; Battles Are Fought in Several Provinces, One 50 Miles From Montevideo.
Peru Censors Revolt Harder Than Uruguay

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: The crew and passengers of the Munson liner Pan America were marooned for several hours yesterday after the liner went aground in low tide not far from her pier at Montague Street, Brooklyn. Coming up the bay from Quarantine, the Pan America, in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The crew and passengers of the Munson liner Pan America were marooned for several hours yesterday after the liner went aground in low tide not far from her pier at Montague Street, Brooklyn. Coming up the bay from Quarantine, the Pan America, in command of Captain Thomas Simmons, backed up suddenly to avoid collision with a lightship passing across her bow.
docs.abstract: Pan America (SS) grounds to avoid collision, near Bklyn pier

headline.main: LINER RUNS AGROUND TO AVERT A CRASH; 63 Passengers on Pan America Marooned Several Hours Near Pier in Brooklyn.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31. -- Uruguayan Government forces suffered a defeat at the hands of revolutionists in a five-hour battle at San Ramon, fifty miles northeast of Montevideo, yesterday, according to reports reaching here today. The rebels shot down...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31. -- Uruguayan Government forces suffered a defeat at the hands of revolutionists in a five-hour battle at San Ramon, fifty miles northeast of Montevideo, yesterday, according to reports reaching here today. The rebels shot down a government plane during the battle, killing its pilot.
docs.abstract: rebels rout loyal troops; Pres Terra said to be relying mainly on police; mutinies reptd

headline.main: URUGUAYAN REBELS ROUT LOYAL TROOPS; Win Battle Fifty Miles From Capital as Their Main Body Eludes Government Forces. MUTINIES ARE REPORTED Terra Is Said to Be Relying Mainly on Police -- Situation Grows More Serious Daily.

byline.original: By JOHN V. WHITE.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1. -- Two definite statements regarding the Uruguayan revolt came from Montevideo today. One was a categorical statement by President Gabriel Terra that "the revolution is all over and finished," and the other was a decree issued...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1. -- Two definite statements regarding the Uruguayan revolt came from Montevideo today. One was a categorical statement by President Gabriel Terra that "the revolution is all over and finished," and the other was a decree issued by him calling up the army and police reserves to double the strength of the present armed forces "during the continuance of the abnormal situation."
docs.abstract: Terra says revolt is over but calls for army and police reserves; Gen B Munoz, rebel, elusive; A G Morales civilian leader of revolt

headline.main: TERRA CALLS MEN TO DOUBLE FORCES; Enrolls Reserves for 'Abnormal Situation' in Uruguay While Declaring Revolt Is Over. REBEL CHIEF IS ELUSIVE Civilians Flee Rivera, Second Largest City, When Munoz Is Reported Marching on It.

byline.original: By JOHN W. WHITE.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LONDON, Feb. 1. -- With diplomatic representatives from the competing nations looking on, Sir Samuel Hoare, president of the British Lawn Tennis Association, today drew from the gleaming silver Davis Cup the pairings for the 1935 international tennis...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Feb. 1. -- With diplomatic representatives from the competing nations looking on, Sir Samuel Hoare, president of the British Lawn Tennis Association, today drew from the gleaming silver Davis Cup the pairings for the 1935 international tennis team competition which sends the United States against China in its first match.

headline.main: U.S. DAVIS CUP TEAM TO OPEN WITH CHINA; Draw Pits Cuba Against Mexico in First Round of North American Zone. DIPLOMATS AT CEREMONY Look On as Sir Samuel Hoare Lifts Pairings From Historic Trophy at London.
STATE CAPITALISM PUSHED BY URUGUAY'S PRESIDENT; Defeat of Old Parties' Rebellion Leaves Terra With Little Opposition and Free To Pursue Centralization Plans
